thread.title: Trump blames ‘liberal activists’ for ‘angry crowds’ in Republican town halls - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Trump blames ‘liberal activists’ for ‘angry crowds’ in Republican town halls - MarketWatch

author: Barbara Kollmeyer
title: Trump blames ‘liberal activists’ for ‘angry crowds’ in Republican town halls - MarketWatch
text:
Across the country, Republican politicians have faced crowds of unhappy constituents back home, and U.S. President Donald Trump says he knows who’s to blame.
“The so-called angry crowds in home districts of some Republicans are actually, in numerous cases, planned out by liberal activists. Sad!” — Donald Trump, U.S. President In a comment on Twitter late Tuesday, Trump said ”liberal activists” were stirring things up for Republicans in their home bases right now.
But as Trump is known to be an avid watcher of Fox News, some said he could have been inspired by a program on that network.
A report on Fox earlier on Tuesday accused Organizing for Action of directing liberals via manuals on how to “crash GOP events and increase the appearance of grassroots resistance” to Trump and his policies. The group’s Facebook page offers a link to this Congressional Recess Toolkit. (Fox News is owned by 21st Century Fox, which was spun off several years ago from News Corp., which owns MarketWatch.)
Some Democrats say they are using the same tactics that the Tea Party used after Barack Obama was elected in 2008.
At a town hall in Colorado on Tuesday, some were flashing ID:
At a town hall in in Colorado, citizens hold up their state IDs to prove to GOP that they are 100% real constituents pic.twitter.com/t2ABatcfJ4
— Kaivan Shroff (@KaivanShroff) February 22, 2017 Some reported packed town halls and GOP congressmen who failed to show:
Remarkable: thousands held town halls in GOP districts across America tonight. Only problem: in many districts they refused to even show up. pic.twitter.com/W2eleGCa2h
— Matt McDermott (@mattmfm) February 22, 2017 Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), among the Republicans who has faced some ire from his constituents, was reportedly met with a standing-room-only crowd for a Des Moines town hall on Tuesday, where he was pressed about eliminating Obamacare , and his views on impeachment:
Chuck Grassley asked about impeachment of Trump at town hall in Garner, Iowa: pic.twitter.com/eAPzQe0pLq
— Vaughn Hillyard (@VaughnHillyard) February 21, 2017 Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) faced the same treatment in a town hall with 130 residents, some of whom peppered her answers on health care and Steve Bannon’s elevation to the National Security Council with boos.
Dave Brat (R-Va.) was criticized for holding a town-hall meeting 60 miles away from the biggest chunk of voters in his district. His office reportedly said that was due to the fact there was no space at a high school where he had originally intended to hold the meeting.
BLACKSTONE, VA - The line outside of a Rep. Dave Brat townhall an hour before it's supposed to start pic.twitter.com/yTXDSGkiJ7
— Ashley Killough (@KilloughCNN) February 21, 2017 More from MarketWatch Who Is Trump's White House Adviser Stephen Miller? Dow books 8th gain in a row as stock market carves up fresh records Ex-Hong Kong leader gets 20 months in prison for misconduct
